title: Great keyboard

title: Absolutely fantastic! ...but...
comment: This keyboard is simply fantastic with just ONE feature it really REALLY needs.  First off, this keyboard is BY FAR the best layout, mimicing a real computer keyboard, so if you're a techie Linux-head like me, you'll love it.  BUT, and this is a deal-breaker for me, it really needs to have "swype" typing (not swype-up) so that I can draw words.  I love that it has a real numeric keypad, cursor controls, function keys... that's great.  The small size of the keys is not hard to take because the touch-hotspots are properly configured to adjust for the width of your fingers and the angle of your view - which many other keyboards get wrong.  If this keyboard had path-typing (swype/swipe typing) then it would be the only keyboard I would ever use again.  I hope the developers think so too.  While I love the layout, I just can't give up path-typing because hunt-and-peck is just too slow for my daily use.  Still, the layout of this keyboard is wonderful for SSH and other techie tasks.  The Kii keyboard is still my best choice thus far, but this one would very quickly become the best with path-typing.  Please add this feature, and I hope you keep up the great work!

title: A Keyboard for Typists
comment: Hacker's Keyboard is a must for people looking to do something USEFUL with the Android operating system.  Otherwise, your smartphone or tablet might as well be a coaster.  You can customize the size, shape, and color of Hacker's Keyboard.  You can also change to Gingerbread layout (if that's your thing).  There are even individual settings for landscape and portrait orientation!  Typical uses for Hacker's Keyboard include word processing, file browsing, and ssh (you know, normal computer stuff).

title: The best keyboard for Android tablets
comment: In my opinion this is the best on-screen keyboard for Android tablets. It presents a full PC-style keyboard, with easy access to function keys such as F1 to F12, PgUp, PgDn, Home, End etc. The layout adapts to the chosen input language, showing keys for the expected letters with diacriticals, placed in their traditional positions. The space taken by the keyboard and the size of the key labels are customizable. I would like to see a possibility to customize the colors and, for the Romanian layout, an option to use the "with cedilla" characters (U+015E/U+015F, U+0162/U+0163) instead of the "with comma below" characters (U+0218/U+0219, U+021A/U+021B) — but those are minor points. Highly recommended.

title: At last! First rate!
comment: My, how this app has improved in recent years – tremendously. Nexus 7 here. After searching and trying out many keyboard schemes, eternally hoping for an Android FITALY, here, at last, is the equivalent of a complete standard desktop hardware keyboard. Although it can work in portrait mode, it really shines in landscape. Dvorak is included, as are 12 function keys. No emoji. The alpha section is one part, and tapping the Fn key brings up the numeric keypad and all the rest. Very nice job!

title: Great

Ctrl and Shift work fine.

The word prediction is different (I can live with this) but the app does not seem to remember often used words (like my salutation and signature for correspondence and e-mail) - this is not enough to out-weigh the app's strengths. I would really like a light theme (like SwitKey's one). I highly recommend this app. **UPDATE:** I have been looking at additional features like 5-row keyboard! Really nice and very complete. Regards, Peter

title: Best in Class Replacement Keyboard for Android!
comment: I do a lot of writing, and the keyboard that comes with Android devices is awful!  Hacker's Keyboard is the first app on all my devices, this keyboard is the best I've found for any serious writing projects.  It is easy to use and in a format any computer user is used to, the typing predictor actually works (even though I keep it off, since it is useless for a writer) which is more than I can say about most of the other keyboards.   This keyboard is the one I use for most of my writing (95% of the time) , if I have a lot of writing to do it is the only one I use, and if I'm editing a document it is the only one that really can be used, a full set of arrow keys is a must for editing a project.   The only other keyboards that I've seen that even come close to Hacker's Keyboard in usefulness & functionality are Swype+Dragon & SwiftKey (I got them free from the other App Store, and the only reason I have them at all) , they are, in my opinion, not nearly as good as Hacker's, I only use them for making quick lists when I'm in a hurry, and swiping a word is not very useful when you're writing.   Hacker's Keyboard for the heavy work, and it does the job very well, we'll worth using!

I'd like to have a Caps Lock key, but other than that, I'm very happy with this app.

title: Excellent for remote work...

Mainly, no "ctrl" key but also the "esc" and the numbers on top. I stumbled across this kb when I was visiting a friend when a router in our system started acting strange. I did a quick search for a different kb and this showed up so I installed it and found that I could even edit a Cisco router from my car on a tablet!!! Since then I have worked remotely on several Linux boxes. Once from a kayak with the tablet tethered to a Droid (both in waterproof bags). Heck, even *I* was in a water proof bag (drysuit). LOL. Highly recommended!!!

title: Shift keys need more isolation in landscape mode
comment: Thanks for the great keyboard! Suggestion for landscape layout improvement: the cost of misthumbtyping shift is very high -- L-shift is near Esc (launches Samsung Digital Frame app in most contexts), and R-shift is between Enter (sends posts b4 finished) and R-arrow (moves to next field in sometimes). If Esc was normal width and left justified there would be room for error below L-shift. Unused area below R-shift would make Return key safer, too. I would gladly trade Spacebar width for that dead space! Thx!

title: Spyware
comment: Using the English version of LBE Security, I can see when this keyboard app is attempting to read my list of contacts and other private data it doesn't need. 1 star for providing the tab key.

The current version (1.37) no longer asks for those permissions. See the FAQ for more information why it used to do so - in short, that was inherited from the default Android keyboard it was based on. The message when activating it is a standard Android warning that appears for all third-party keyboards, it's not related to the security scanner.

A click response would let me know immediately that I'd not hit the key properly. Other than that I can practically touch-type (typing while looking at the text area or even the source material that is being copied, without watching my fingers all the time) on this - which, on a flat surface with no tactile feedback, is amazing to me.  Acer Iconia Tab A700 10.1inch

title: Very Dangerous App!!!

Why? Of course because without permissions it cannot steal what you type and your dictionary data.... it was immediately uninstalled!!!....

Please see https://code.google.com/p/hackerskeyboard/wiki/FrequentlyAskedQuestions for more information about the security warning and permissions, which I've inherited from the original Gingerbread keyboard that this is based on.

title: Best keyboard for Android
comment: I have used other keyboards for Android, including MessagEase, but ultimately I switched to this one.  It's the little things that make the difference. In my case the important ones are:  * there is support for a lot of languages (so when typing in Polish I don't have to skip all the language-specific diacritics) * there's the *extremely* useful feature of easily bringing the keyboard up manually. Of course, there is no comparison to the default keyboard provided on my Samsung tablet. * no glitches or bugs, which some other otherwise decent keyboards do have.  All in all, perfect.

title: Even on a phone it's amazing
comment: I have a pretty low-end smart phone but I do use connectbot to SSH into my computer and into my Unix shell account at SDF.org. Even in portrait mode with the five row keyboard, it is still a joy to type on (though if my eyesight were poor it'd be extremely difficult) so kudos on making a fine, adaptable app. It isn't my main keyboard, but for nerdy tasks it is absolutely essential!   EDIT and update: It really comes into its own on my tablet where it is indispensable for remote access into computers at work.

title: A relief to have a real keyboard !
comment: For any editing of text one needs real cursor keys, not to mention some others that are absent on or difficult to get to on standard droid keyboards. I found the Hackers keyboard, tried it and immediately wiped the ICS keyboard app from my Gingerbread phone, as this one is way better. Like the ICS keyboard app, you can not move it to the SD card, which is logical as it is part of the phone's interface even if you switch memory cards. So once you have found the best keyboard ap for your kind of use, delete the others... I feel that I'm going to keep this one as my standard keyboard. Any pocket computer needs a decent form of text input, and this is it. Keep up the good work.

This is the first app ever to have made me really, really happy. Creating and honing this is a great achievement, and a boon to humanity.  Can't wait to see if I can tweak it to be as usefull on my phone (Moto Defy) as on my tablet.  Oh, and I am NOT a coder, I am a writer. Some improvements I would like:  - The sound feedback should have a separate configurable volume. I want to use sound feedback (on key press), but it's often too loud with Hacker's keyboard so I disable it. (+and some alternate sound themes would be welcome)  - The letters on the keys could be a little bit smaller (font size) so they could fit better. They look a bit too big+bold.  - The big-letter preview (when you hit a key) would be a nice feature if it was more aesthetically pleasant (smooth antialiased graphics). Perhaps a bit of transparency. Definitely a good feature to improve upon.  - I like the default graphics theme, I wish there were a couple more available. Or better, adjustable brightness+hue of the keys and the letters, with presets.  Thanks!

title: Good in specific scenarios, but not the best daily
comment: TL;DR: ** I found SwiftKey's error correction during fast type gave very accurate results, significantly more accurate than the other 2 keyboards I tried, and hence it was the most efficient **   --   Full story: I trialed 3 android keyboards (Go, Hacker's, SwiftKey) in both orientations (portrait, landscape) and with 3 typing styles (accurate type, fast type, slide). I expect to generally use portrait mode so I was more focused on this. SwiftKey significantly outperformed the other 2 with it's error correction even while fast-typing. Other than error correction, Go and SwiftKey are very similar products. Hacker's keyboard is somewhat more specialised: it (optionally) supports a full 5 row qwerty (inc. a number row) even in portrait mode. Having used SwiftKey more, I now tend to just long press the top row to get individual numbers (and this is fast enough to outweigh giving up screen estate for the extra row). I can imagine using this keyboard occasionally, particularly in landscape mode, to take advantage of the full keyboard/number row and possibly to try out the Dvorak layout.

title: Very good but not perfect
comment: I like that this keyboard has cursor keys and puts the numbers above the letters, so that everything I need is available without having to go to another screen. Ability to type by speaking is also a very nice feature, do it sometimes gets things wrong. Left the previous sentence as it is so that you can see what kind of mistakes the audio speaking thing makes. One thing I really miss about this keyboard is there is no clicking sound when I type. It helps to hear the sound that the keys make, because this helps me avoid missing key presses. The main problem I have typing on this keyboard is that the spacebar doesn't always respond, and Isometimes end up writing words with no spaces between them, as I did earlier in this sentence. Also, because this is a full keyboard, typing is more cramped, and I have to be more careful about making typos. Although this keyboard makes it easier to correct mistakes then the default keyboard does, I am also more prone to making mistakes when I use it. So I sometimes use the default keyboard instead, with which I can type faster without making as many mistakes.

Yes through Hacker's keyboard you get arrow keys!  But gripes:  1. Keys are too crowded together.  2. No noise when you tap on a key.  3. Keys need some leeway from the Honeycomb-status-bar-soft-key-option-bar-thing-at-bottom-of-screen, I often hit the Honeycomb-status-bar-soft-key-option-bar-thing-at-bottom-of-screen when typing.  4. Made like a COMPUTER keyboard, making for some situations where you hit the backslash key instead of backspace.    3/5, good for replacing default keyboard, kudos to the developers for putting arrow keys, but it needs more polish.

title: Perfect, while the others are garbage
comment: This guy has really nailed it. The idea of not teaching the user a different layout, but bringing as much as possible of the PC keyboard layout experience is brilliant and very skillfully made.  This keyboard is what turns my Samsung Tab from a beautiful but useless gadget (as far as entering text or programming is concerned) into a fully functional PC replacement. I can now enter blog posts, work on my papers, program as well as I do on my laptop. I even have a numeric keypad. I have arrows, shift-selecting text, ctrl-X, -C, -V and everything else. And the plethora of options is amazing.  Very well done, Klaus! Thank you! EDIT: I am sorry to say that there are some non-intelligent life-forms here saying that this keyboard is collecting private user data, passwords etc. To bring some light into their dark night, that is the standard warning that Android issues for ANY 3rd party keyboard layout. The worst thing is that these stupid people rate poorly this wonderful piece of software and this brings his general ratings down. Come on people, grow a brain!
